questions.prompt: In BG 13.1, what does Arjuna ask Krishna to explain?
choices: How to rule a kingdom without losing authority
The field and the knower of the field
How sacrifices grant enjoyment in higher worlds
How to master pranayama as the only yoga
questions.feedback: Arjuna asks about ksetra (the field) and ksetra-jna (the knower of the field). This frames the chapter as disciplined discrimination between matter and consciousness. If this boundary is blurred, spiritual life turns into either bodily religiosity or abstract speculation. Clear categories are the doorway to liberation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.2, who is the knower of the field within the body?
choices: The gross body and its biological functions
The subtle mind and its stream of thoughts
The individual soul within the body
The senses working through the nervous system
questions.feedback: Krishna states that the atma is the ksetra-jna, the conscious knower of the field. Body, mind, and senses are parts of the field, not the observer. This corrects the error of calling brain activity or sensory data the self. The knower remains distinct from what is known.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.2, what does Prabhupada stress about the 'knower of the field' across all bodies?
choices: Each body has a different supreme knower
The same individual soul occupies all bodies
The Supreme Knower is one in all bodies
Only human bodies contain a real knower
questions.feedback: Prabhupada highlights that while each body has its individual knower (the jiva), the Supreme Knower is the same everywhere as Paramatma. A false path is to reduce consciousness to biology or to deny the Supreme Witness. The Witness is equal in all, yet karma still operates with real consequence. Real knowledge includes both the finite knower and the Supreme Knower.

questions.prompt: In BG 13.3, what does Krishna say qualifies as true knowledge?
choices: Knowing how the body works through analysis
Knowing both the field and the knower
Knowing the mind as the final self within
Knowing the senses as the true controller
questions.feedback: Krishna states that understanding both ksetra and ksetra-jna is real knowledge. If one studies the field alone, one stays trapped in material analysis. If one speaks of spirit without identifying the field, one drifts into vague mysticism. Knowledge becomes liberating when the observer and the observed are clearly separated.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.5, how does Krishna indicate the knowledge of the field has been described?
choices: By private intuition without any authority
By multiple sages in various Vedic writings
By argument alone without scriptural anchor
By denying scripture in favor of sensation
questions.feedback: Krishna points to a consistent Vedic tradition describing the field. This protects the student from inventing private metaphysics. It also prevents cherry-picking one verse while ignoring the broader scriptural picture. A steady chain of authority anchors discrimination in revealed knowledge.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.6-7, what does Krishna classify as part of the field (ksetra)?
choices: Only the physical body and its chemistry
Body plus the subtle mind-intellect-ego
Only the soul and its consciousness
Only Paramatma and His supervision
questions.feedback: Krishna includes both gross and subtle components within the field. This blocks a common mistake: thinking the mind is the self because it is internal. The field is everything that can be observed, including mental states. The knower is the one who experiences these changes.

questions.prompt: In BG 13.7, why does Krishna list items like desire, hatred, happiness, distress, and the aggregate?
choices: To show the complete range of what is non-self
To prove emotions are the eternal soul itself
To deny that consciousness is a distinct reality
To claim the body is eternal and independent
questions.feedback: Krishna is mapping the full field, including inner experiences often mistaken for identity. Desire and hatred feel personal, but they are movements within the field. This analytical list trains the seeker to stop calling shifting states the self. The knower remains constant while the field fluctuates.

questions.prompt: In BG 13.8-12, which set best represents the core of knowledge Krishna praises?
choices: Humility, nonviolence, tolerance, and simplicity
Influence, eloquence, prestige, and intensity
Severe austerity without changing the heart
Exact ritual method without inner reform
questions.feedback: Krishna defines knowledge by transformed character, not by information alone. If pride grows with study, the study has not become knowledge. These qualities weaken the false ego that claims ownership and superiority. Knowledge is recognized by how it purifies the knower.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.8-12, what is the practical test of whether one has real knowledge?
choices: Defeating opponents through superior debate
Gaining followers through public reputation
Becoming humble and detached in daily life
Collecting complex methods and secret skills
questions.feedback: Prabhupada stresses that knowledge must show up as humility, restraint, and detachment. A false path is to mistake scholarship for realization and then become proud. When knowledge is real, it reduces the urge to dominate and to enjoy separately from Krishna. This protects bhakti from turning into ego disguised as philosophy.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.10, what does 'constant and unalloyed devotion to Me' indicate about knowledge?
choices: Devotion is optional if one has knowledge
Devotion is a defining limb of knowledge
Devotion blocks knowledge by emotion alone
Devotion is only for beginners to start
questions.feedback: Krishna includes devotion as part of knowledge, not as a separate sentimental add-on. If knowledge does not move toward service, it remains incomplete. A false path is to treat jnana as superior and bhakti as secondary. Here, Krishna ties real knowledge to devotion to the Supreme Person.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.10, why does Prabhupada warn against detachment without devotion?
choices: Because consciousness cannot remain empty for long
Because detachment always destroys the soul
Because devotion is only external ritual work
Because detachment is never recommended at all
questions.feedback: Prabhupada emphasizes that consciousness must be engaged; it cannot stay in a vacuum. Detachment without higher attachment often collapses into voidism or dry negation. The real move is transfer of attachment from matter to Krishna through service. This purport targets false renunciation that tries to stop desire without purifying desire.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.12, what is the ultimate object of knowledge Krishna describes?
choices: The ever-changing material field alone
The individual soul alone, without God
The Supreme Person to be known
The impersonal brahman without any person
questions.feedback: Krishna presents Himself as the supreme knowable object. Knowledge that stops at analysis of matter or even at the jiva remains partial. A false path is to treat the Absolute as merely impersonal energy while ignoring the Supreme Person. Real knowledge culminates in knowing Krishna and relating to Him.

questions.prompt: In BG 13.13, how does Krishna describe His presence in existence?
choices: Present everywhere, without being limited
Present only in sacred places, not elsewhere
Present only in the spiritual world, not here
Present only in humans, not in animals
questions.feedback: Krishna explains His all-pervasiveness. This corrects the idea that God is distant or absent from ordinary life. It also avoids the error of thinking God is only a concept. The Supreme is present everywhere, yet remains Supreme.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.14-17, how is Krishna 'everywhere' without becoming matter?
choices: He becomes the material elements themselves
He pervades as Paramatma while staying transcendental
He is only in one place but imagined everywhere
He dissolves individuality into impersonal energy
questions.feedback: Prabhupada explains that Krishna pervades creation as Paramatma while remaining distinct from matter. This rejects pantheism (God equals matter) and deism (God is absent). A false path is to flatten God into the universe and call that spirituality. Krishna is present within the field yet never reduced to the field.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.16, which description best matches the Supersoul's role?
choices: Dependent on nature and produced by matter
Indwelling witness and sustainer of all
Inactive observer with no influence at all
Temporary force that ends with the body
questions.feedback: Krishna describes Himself as seated in every heart and as the source, maintainer, and end of all. This means existence is not self-sustaining or independent. A false path is to believe the universe runs without a Supreme regulator. The Supersoul is intimate and governing, not distant and irrelevant.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.17, how does Prabhupada clarify the Lord being 'situated everywhere' while remaining distinct?
choices: The Lord becomes identical with every material object
The Lord pervades by His energies and remains the Supreme
The Lord is absent, and presence is only poetic language
The Lord is only within humans, not within other species
questions.feedback: Prabhupada clarifies that the Lord is all-pervading without being reduced to matter. His presence is real and active, yet He remains the Supreme Person, distinct from the field. This blocks two false paths: pantheism that equates God with matter, and materialism that treats divine presence as metaphor. The student learns to see presence without collapsing the categories of God and nature.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.18, what is the key takeaway about the field and the knower in every living being?
choices: The field alone exists, and the knower is imagined
Each being is a combination of field and knower, distinct
The knower is only a product of the subtle mind
The knower and field are ultimately the same entity
questions.feedback: Prabhupada emphasizes that every living being involves both the field (body and subtle apparatus) and the knower (the jiva), which are distinct. The false path is to collapse the observer into the observed and call it realization. Discrimination protects bhakti: devotion is meant for the Supreme Person, not for the temporary field. When the knower is forgotten, life becomes doership and enjoyment inside the field.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.21-22, what is the core mistake that binds the soul to the modes and to repeated birth?
choices: Identifying as the enjoyer within the field
Serving Krishna through regulated practice
Seeing Paramatma as the supreme witness
Rejecting bodily identity through knowledge
questions.feedback: Prabhupada stresses that the enjoyer mentality binds the jiva to the modes and their consequences. The soul then accepts good and evil as its own identity, and the mode association drives future bodies. A false path is to think bondage is merely external, without addressing the inner claim to enjoy separately. This targets the root of doership and enjoyment, not just external habits.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.23, which role is explicitly attributed to the Supersoul?
choices: Observer, permitter, and ultimate witness
Temporary product of the subtle mind
Collective psyche formed by society
Personal imagination used for comfort
questions.feedback: Krishna describes the Supersoul as the witness and permitter within the heart. This preserves both intimacy and accountability in spiritual life. A false path is to treat inner conscience as merely psychological and therefore negotiable. The Supersoul observes, sanctions, and guides, even when the jiva forgets.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.24, which approach is specifically mentioned for perceiving the Supersoul within oneself?
choices: Meditation and disciplined inner vision
Economic charity as the highest yoga
Political reform as the main spiritual path
Sense enjoyment offered as worship
questions.feedback: Krishna mentions dhyana and inner perception of the Supersoul. This does not contradict bhakti; it explains one doorway for perceiving the indwelling Lord. A false path is to use meditation to erase the personhood of God and end in impersonalism. Right meditation aims at the Supreme Person within the heart.

questions.prompt: In BG 13.25, why does Krishna describe multiple paths (meditation, analysis, and work)?
choices: Because truth changes with each tradition
Because temperaments differ while the goal is one
Because all methods are equal in every respect
Because only one method works for anyone
questions.feedback: Krishna accommodates different natures while keeping a unified aim: realization of the self and the Supreme. This rejects sectarian rigidity without endorsing lazy relativism. Methods differ, but success depends on genuine movement toward realization and surrender. The false path is to treat variety as permission to avoid the goal.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.26, what does Prabhupada emphasize about prakriti and purusa in relation to Krishna?
choices: Both exist independently with no supreme source
Both originate from Krishna as the supreme cause
Prakriti creates Krishna through evolution over time
Purusa creates prakriti by mental projection alone
questions.feedback: Prabhupada explains that both the field and the knower have their origin in Krishna. This defeats two false paths at once: materialism (matter produces consciousness) and idealism (consciousness invents matter). Both are real but dependent, and Krishna is the independent reality. This keeps personalism as the chapter's conclusion, not impersonal abstraction.

questions.prompt: According to BG 13.27, what equal vision is described regarding the Supersoul?
choices: The Supersoul is present equally in all beings
The Supersoul is present only in the learned
The Supersoul is present only in the pious
The Supersoul is present only in humans
questions.feedback: Krishna states that the Paramatma is situated equally within all living beings. This gives the basis for non-envious respect toward all life. It does not mean all behavior is equally pure or all choices are equally wise. Equal presence supports compassion, not moral confusion.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.28-29, how does Prabhupada prevent the mistake: 'If God is equal in all, then all actions are the same'?
choices: He denies karma and responsibility altogether
He distinguishes spiritual equality from karmic difference
He claims bodies alone determine moral value
He teaches that sin has no practical effect
questions.feedback: Prabhupada keeps two truths together: Paramatma is equal in all, and karma still operates with real consequences. A false path is naive egalitarianism that excuses harmful action by quoting spiritual oneness. Compassion means seeing the soul, while also recognizing the field's laws and responsibility. Spiritual vision sharpens discernment; it does not cancel it.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 13.34-35, what is the concluding requirement for liberation described at the end of the chapter?
choices: Only technical analysis, without devotion, is enough
Seeing the field and knower distinctly, with devotion to Krishna
Denying the soul and treating consciousness as matter
Rejecting the Supersoul and trusting the mind alone
questions.feedback: Prabhupada emphasizes that discrimination must mature into Krishna-centered realization, not remain dry theory. The field and knower must be seen distinctly, and the Supreme Knower must be honored as the source and guide. A false path is to study distinction and then stop short of surrender, keeping the ego as the final authority. Liberation comes when knowledge and devotion unite into steady Krishna consciousness.
